subject: Personal Finance
title: The Purchasing Power Illusion
description: One-minute skill: The Purchasing Power Illusion.

hook.text: Your grandparents bought a house for $20,000. That sounds cheap until you adjust for inflation.

buildup.text: Comparing prices across decades without adjusting is meaningless. Dollars change value.

discovery.text: $20,000 in 1960 is equivalent to roughly $200,000 today. The 'cheap' house wasn't so cheap.

twist.text: People nostalgic for old prices forget that old wages were proportionally lower too.

climax.text: What matters isn't the price tag. It's how many hours of work something costs you.

punchline.text: Old prices look cheap. Old wages don't.

quiz.question: Why can't you simply compare prices across decades?
options: The value of money changes over time
